qas.question: What did the Queen commission Sir Robert Peel to do?
In what year did Melbourne resign?
Which party was Sir Robert Peel a part of?
What is the name of crisis where the wives of the Tories were replacing the wives of the Whigs?
What year did Melbourne resign?
Who voted against the bill to end the constitution of Jamaica?
Who did the Queen commission to form a new ministry?

The removal of the Queens bedchamber ladies became known as what?
Who resigned their position in 1839?
Why did the Radicals and Tories oppose the bill about the constitution of Jamaica?

answers.text: The bill removed political power from plantation owners who were resisting measures associated with the abolition of slavery.

qas.question: What Tory did Victoria commision after Melbourne resigned his postion?
After Queen Victoria refuse to replace her ladies with wives of Tories, what did Sir Robert Peel do?
Who did Victoria reappoint to the position after the Bedchamber Crisis?
What did the Radicals and Tories do that made Melbourne resign?

answers.text: voted against a bill to suspend the constitution of Jamaica

qas.question: Which group was resisting the abolisment of slavery and were subsequently removed from power when the bill was voted down?
Who did Robert Peel want to replace the ladies of the bedchamber with, instead of wives of Whigs?
Why did Peel resign his comission?

answers.text: Peel refused to govern under the restrictions imposed by the Queen

qas.question: Who returned to office after Peel resigned?
What did the King commission Sir Robert Peel to do?
In what year did Melbourne get hired?
Which party wasn't Sir Robert Peel a part of?
What is the name of crisis where the husbands of the Tories were replacing the wives of the Whigs?
Who voted for the bill to end the constitution of Jamaica?

context: In <a1_0><a4_0><b20_0>1839<b20_0/><a4_0/><a1_0/>, <a9_0>Melbourne<a9_0/> resigned after <a5_0><b23_0>Radicals and Tories<b23_0/><a5_0/> (both of whom Victoria detested) <a14_0>voted against a bill to suspend the constitution of Jamaica<a14_0/>. <a10_0>The bill removed political power from <a15_0>plantation owners<a15_0/> who were resisting measures associated with the abolition of slavery.<a10_0/> The Queen commissioned a <a2_0><b21_0>Tory<b21_0/><a2_0/>, <a6_0><a11_0>Sir Robert Peel<a11_0/><a6_0/>, <a0_0><b19_0>to form a new ministry<b19_0/><a0_0/>. At the time, it was customary for the prime minister to appoint members of the Royal Household, who were usually his political allies and their spouses. Many of the Queen's ladies of the bedchamber were wives of Whigs, and Peel expected to replace them with <a16_0>wives of Tories<a16_0/>. In what became known as <a8_0>the <a3_0><b22_0>bedchamber crisis<b22_0/><a8_0/><a3_0/>, Victoria, advised by Melbourne, objected to their removal. <a17_0>Peel refused to govern under the restrictions imposed by the Queen<a17_0/>, and consequently <a12_0>resigned his commission<a12_0/>, allowing <a7_0><a13_0><a18_0>Melbourne<a18_0/><a13_0/><a7_0/> to return to office.
